content.body: tbh i'd say that if the catch is in a separate file from the finally, then the finally file probably shouldn't be assuming the promise is handled

* tbh i'd say that if the catch is in a separate file from the finally, then the finally file probably shouldn't be assuming the promise is handled - iow, the author of one file shouldn't assume knowledge of the code in another one

m.new_content.body: tbh i'd say that if the catch is in a separate file from the finally, then the finally file probably shouldn't be assuming the promise is handled - iow, the author of one file shouldn't assume knowledge of the code in another one

content.body: Hey! I have a random question: was the idea of `Array.prototype.clear()` ever struck down in TC39? I've had repeated experiences of `array.length = 0` not being trusted by developers, despite being the best way to do clear an array, so I was thinking if a `.clear()` proposal would have a future
content.formatted_body: Hey! I have a random question: was the idea of Array.prototype.clear() ever struck down in TC39? I've had repeated experiences of array.length = 0 not being trusted by developers, despite being the best way to do clear an array, so I was thinking if a .clear() proposal would have a future

content.body: Just coming from Python, Java, C#, Rust, or almost any language, you expect `.clear()`
content.formatted_body: Just coming from Python, Java, C#, Rust, or almost any language, you expect .clear()

content.body: Why would `.clear` be trusted more? Btw, you can also use `arr.splice(0, arr.length)`
content.formatted_body: Why would .clear be trusted more? Btw, you can also use arr.splice(0, arr.length)

content.body: It _seems_ sketchy, despite being valid, which is just an odd developer experience
content.formatted_body: It seems sketchy, despite being valid, which is just an odd developer experience
